awd_abstract_narration:
Bush
DMS-1614043

     Macroscopic physics is deterministic, with predictability limited only by the intrusion of chaos.  Conversely, microscopic physics is widely thought to be intrinsically probabilistic, the statistical predictions of quantum mechanics a complete description of the microscopic world.  A decade ago, Yves Couder and co-workers in Paris discovered the first quantum analog system.  The system, consisting of millimeter-sized droplets self-propelling along the surface of a vibrating fluid bath, represents a macroscopic realization of the pilot-wave mechanics proposed by Louis de Broglie in the 1920s for microscopic quantum particles.  The fact that this hydrodynamic system exhibits quantum-like statistical behavior raises the question as to whether there really is a qualitative difference between the microscopic and macroscopic worlds.  The investigators explore this question by studying the potential and limitations of this hydrodynamic system as a quantum analogue.  Graduate students are involved in the work of the project.

     The walking-droplet system raises a number of fascinating new mathematical questions concerning the dynamics and statistics of wave-particle systems in which a particle generates a wave field, then moves in response to it.  The investigator and co-investigator have developed a theoretical framework for describing this system, a hierarchy of mathematical models of increasing sophistication that have been carefully benchmarked against experiment.  The project is directed towards rationalizing the stability of single- and multiple-droplet static and dynamic states by analyzing, extending and adapting these models.  Specifically, we analyze the stability of both steady and periodic solutions to the model equations.  Particular attention is given to rationalizing the interactions of multiple droplets of equal or unequal size, pairs and lattices, which are known to exhibit a variety of novel dynamical bound states and instabilities.  New rationale for the behavior of single and multiple droplets is sought through an energetic analysis, by assessing the relative magnitudes of the global energies of the accessible solutions of the model equations.  Theoretical developments are guided and constrained by a supporting experimental program conducted in parallel in MIT's Applied Math Laboratory.

Fifteen years ago, it was discovered that a liquid drop could self-propel across the surface of a vibrating bath by virtue of its resonant interaction with its own guiding or `pilot' wave field (Figure 1). The resulting coupling between drop and wave, the so-called `walker', represents a macroscopic example of a particle dressed in a wave. As such, it exhibits many features thought to be exclusive to microscopic, quantum particles. Remarkably, it represents a macroscopic realization of de Louis Broglie's pilot-wave theory, proposed in the 1920s, wherein quantum particles move in resonance with a field generated by the particle vibration.For the past decade, the PI's research has been directed towards exploring the potential and limitations of this hydrodynamic system as a quantum analog. In so doing, it raises important questions as to the necessity of the schism that currently exists between macroscopic and microscopic physics, and the philosophical extravagance of modern quantum philosophy. The critical feature of the hydrodynamicpilot-wave system is `memory', as is responsible for the emergence of quantized states and quantum-likestatistics in a number of settings. The memory of the system is rooted in the fact that the propulsive forceacting on the droplet depends on its past trajectory, hence, one cannot predict its future without knowledge of its past. It is through this memory that quantum-like correlations emerge that can not be accounted for without consideration of the pilot wave.


Our DMS-funded project was concerned with the interactions of multiple droplets (Figure 2). Prior to our work, a number of different bound states were known to exist for both static bouncers and walkers. A number of new such states were discovered during the course of this project, including droplet rings (Figure 3). In general, a discrete set of stable bound states may be found when the distance between adjacent drops, the bond length, takes on a quantized value prescribed by the wave field. Our work on this project resulted in a number of important conceptual advances in our understanding of the stability and dynamics of such bound states of droplets. Specifically, our work highlighted the importance of both modulations in the vertical dynamics and transient waves, effects neglected in prior theoretical models. Our work has thus lead to the development of a new generation of mathematical models that incorporate these relativelysubtle effects, and are critical in rationalizing the observed behavior of walker bound states. This new generation of theoretical models has been successfully applied in studies of the stability and dynamics of bouncing and orbiting droplet pairs, and is currently being applied to droplet rings and lattices.


Our theoretical modeling has enabled us to establish new connections with theoretical models of interacting vortices and crystal vibrations, and so forged new links with a number of canonical systems in hydrodynamics and solid-state physics, thereby expanding the range of physical analogy of the bouncing droplet system. Such connections are vital in extending the range of hydrodynamic quantum analogs, and attracting new contributors to this exciting new field. Our work is widely disseminated through our published work, through presentations given at invited seminars and meetings of the American Physical Society, and on the PI's webpage. Our project is highlighted in our entry in the NSF We Are Mathematics Video Competition, entitled entitled "Pilot-wave dynamics: a mathematical bridge".
